concepts.title: Reduce, Reuse, Recycle in Daily Life
concepts.content: The 3R principle тАФ Reduce (рдХрдореА рдХрд░рд╛), Reuse (рдкреБрдиреНрд╣рд╛ рд╡рд╛рдкрд░рд╛), Recycle (рдкреБрдирд░реНрд╡рд╛рдкрд░ рдХрд░рд╛) тАФ is the foundation of sustainable living. (1) Reduce means buying and consuming less тАФ only get what you truly need; (2) Reuse means finding new uses for old items instead of throwing them away; (3) Recycle means processing old materials (paper, glass, plastic, metal) into new products. In the chapter, Jordan's conversation with his mother shows how old, worn clothes тАФ instead of being thrown away тАФ can be repurposed into useful items. This saves money, reduces waste, and is good for the environment. The Marathi concept is: 'рдЬреЗ рдЖрд╣реЗ рддреЗ рд╡рд╛рдкрд░рд╛' (use what you have).

examples.text: Old cotton clothes тЖТ cut into strips тЖТ woven into a doormat (рдЪрдЯрдИ) тАФ a practical reuse of worn fabric.
Old jeans or thick cloth тЖТ stitched into a purse (рдкрд░реНрд╕) тАФ creative upcycling, saves money on buying new bags.
Old fabric strips тЖТ tied and woven into a decorative toran (рддреЛрд░рдг) for the door тАФ beautiful and eco-friendly.
India produces 1 million tonnes of textile waste per year тАФ reusing old clothes makes a significant environmental impact.

keyPoints: 3R principle: Reduce (less consumption), Reuse (new uses for old items), Recycle (process into new materials).
Priority order: REDUCE is best (don't create waste), then REUSE, then RECYCLE.
Upcycling (creative reuse) gives old items new life and value тАФ not just recycling but upgrading.
Maharashtra's 'rag pickers' (рдХрдЪрд░рд╛ рд╡реЗрдЪрдгрд╛рд░реЗ) do important recycling work тАФ they deserve respect for their environmental contribution.
Every family can practice 3R тАФ it saves money AND protects the environment.

concepts.title: What Jordan and Mother Make from Old Clothes
concepts.content: In the chapter's core conversation, Jordan and mother transform old, unusable clothes into three beautiful and useful items: (1) Purse (рдкрд░реНрд╕) тАФ old jeans or thick fabric is cut and stitched into a carrying bag. (2) Toran (рддреЛрд░рдг) тАФ old colourful fabric strips are tied and twisted into a decorative hanging for the door. In Maharashtra's tradition, torans (made from mango leaves, marigolds, or cloth) are hung on doorways for auspicious occasions and festivals. (3) Doormat (рдкрд╛рдпрдкреБрд╕рдгреА / рдЪрдЯрдИ) тАФ old cotton clothes are cut into strips and woven or braided into a doormat. These activities show that creativity + old materials = useful products, saving money and reducing waste.

examples.text: Purse from old denim: cut two rectangular pieces, stitch three sides, add a zip or button тАФ done! Functional and unique.
Toran from old saree strips: cut colourful cloth into strips, tie them along a string тАФ beautiful door decoration.
Doormat from old towels/cotton clothes: cut into long strips, braid them together тАФ a thick, durable mat.
Cost to make: almost zero (using waste material). Cost to buy: тВ╣150-500 per item. Clear financial benefit!

Toran = decorative hanging for doorways тАФ traditional in Maharashtra's home decoration for festivals.
These activities develop creativity, practical skills, and environmental responsibility simultaneously.
The conversation format (Jordan + mother) shows this as a family activity тАФ involving children in eco-friendly practices.
Marathi households traditionally hated waste тАФ old saris became floor cloths, old dhotis became cleaning rags. This is that tradition updated!

concepts.title: Computer Safety Rules
concepts.content: The chapter includes important computer and internet safety rules, presented in a Marathi context for students. Key rules: (1) Do not share your passwords (рд╕рдВрдХреЗрддрд╢рдмреНрдж) with anyone тАФ not even friends; (2) Do not talk to strangers online or share personal information (name, address, school, phone number); (3) Tell a trusted adult immediately if you see something uncomfortable or disturbing online; (4) Do not click on unknown links or download files from unknown sources; (5) Use the computer only for the time permitted by parents; (6) Never upload personal photos to public websites without parent permission. These rules apply to mobile phones, tablets, and computers equally.

examples.text: Passwords: 'рд╕рдВрдХреЗрддрд╢рдмреНрдж' (password) should be secret тАФ like a house key, never share it with anyone.
No personal info online: never share address, school name, phone number with people you haven't met in person.
Cyberbullying: if someone online is rude, threatening, or making you uncomfortable тАФ tell a parent or teacher immediately.
Screen time: balanced use тАФ parents and children agree on usage time. Too much screen time affects sleep and study.

keyPoints: рд╕рдВрдХреЗрддрд╢рдмреНрдж (password) = never share with anyone including friends.
Personal information is private: name, address, school, phone, photos тАФ never share online with strangers.
If uncomfortable online: tell a trusted adult (parent, teacher) immediately тАФ never ignore it.
Unknown links and downloads are dangerous тАФ they may contain viruses or lead to scams.
Balanced screen time: technology is a tool, not a lifestyle тАФ use it wisely and with parental guidance.
concepts.funFact: India has the world's second-largest internet user base (after China) тАФ and millions of school students use the internet daily. Maharashtra's Cyber Crime Department received over 5,000 complaints from minors in one recent year alone. Learning cyber safety is as important as learning road safety тАФ the digital world has its own 'traffic rules'!

concepts.title: Marathi Spelling Rule тАФ рдЕрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреНрддрд╛рдкреВрд░реНрд╡реАрдЪреЗ рджреАрд░реНрдШ рдЗрдХрд╛рд░/рдЙрдХрд╛рд░
concepts.content: An important Marathi spelling rule: In native Marathi words (not Sanskrit-origin words), when a word ends in a consonant (рдЕрдХрд╛рд░рд╛рдиреНрдд = ending in the рдЕ sound), the 'рдЗ' (short i) or 'рдЙ' (short u) vowel that comes just BEFORE the final consonant should be written as LONG: 'рдИ' (long i) or 'рдК' (long u). In simple terms: the vowel right before the LAST consonant in many Marathi words is long. Examples: рдорд╛рдгреВрд╕ (person тАФ рдК before рд╕), рдЧрд░реАрдм (poor тАФ рдИ before рдм), рдлреВрд▓ (flower тАФ рдК before рд▓), рдкрд╛рдКрд▓ (step/footstep тАФ рдК before рд▓), рдХрд╛рдЪреВрд│, рдорд╛рд╕реВрд▓. EXCEPTION: Sanskrit-origin words (рддрддреНрд╕рдо рд╢рдмреНрдж) keep their original Sanskrit spelling: рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереА, рдХрд╡реА, рдЧреБрд░реБ (not рдЧреВрд░реВ).

examples.text: рдорд╛рдгреВрд╕ (person): the рдК before final рд╕ is LONG тАФ write рдорд╛рдгреВрд╕, NOT рдорд╛рдгреБрд╕.
рдлреВрд▓ (flower): the рдК before final рд▓ is LONG тАФ write рдлреВрд▓, NOT рдлреБрд▓.
рдЧрд░реАрдм (poor): the рдИ before final рдм is LONG тАФ write рдЧрд░реАрдм, NOT рдЧрд░рд┐рдм.
рдкрд╛рдКрд▓ (step): the рдК before final рд▓ is LONG тАФ write рдкрд╛рдКрд▓, NOT рдкрд╛рдЙрд▓.

keyPoints: Rule: In Marathi words, the рдЗ/рдЙ vowel before the last consonant is written LONG (рджреАрд░реНрдШ) тАФ as рдИ/рдК.
Examples: рдорд╛рдгреВрд╕ (person), рдлреВрд▓ (flower), рдЧрд░реАрдм (poor), рдкрд╛рдКрд▓ (step), рдХрд╛рд│реВрдХ, рджреВрдз (milk).
Exception: Sanskrit-origin (рддрддреНрд╕рдо) words keep their original Sanskrit spelling тАФ рд╡рд┐рджреНрдпрд╛рд░реНрдереА, рдХрд╡реА, рд╕рд╛рд╣рд┐рддреНрдп.
This rule helps in correct Marathi spelling (рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд▓реЗрдЦрди) тАФ a frequent exam topic.
Check: Is the word a native Marathi word? If yes, apply the рджреАрд░реНрдШ rule. If Sanskrit-origin, keep original.
concepts.funFact: Marathi spelling standardization (рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд▓реЗрдЦрди) was a major project in the 20th century. The Maharashtra government's Marathi Language Department worked to create standard spelling rules so that all textbooks, newspapers, and government documents would have consistent spelling. Before standardization, the same word could be spelled differently by different authors!

concepts.title: Marathi Proverbs (рдореНрд╣рдгреА) and Their Meanings
concepts.content: Marathi proverbs (рдореНрд╣рдгреА) are short, traditional sayings that carry deep wisdom in very few words. They are used in daily speech, stories, and essays. Three important рдореНрд╣рдгреА from this chapter: (1) 'рдЕрддрд┐ рддреЗрдереЗ рдорд╛рддреА' тАФ 'where there is excess, there is ruin'; too much of anything leads to harm. (2) 'рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рддрд│реЗ рд╕рд╛рдЪреЗ' тАФ 'drop by drop, a lake is formed'; small, consistent efforts accumulate into great results. (3) 'рдЧрд░реНрд╡рд╛рдЪреЗ рдШрд░ рдЦрд╛рд▓реА' тАФ 'pride's house is empty'; arrogance/pride leads to downfall. These three proverbs capture values of moderation, patience, and humility тАФ core values of Maharashtra's cultural wisdom.

examples.text: 'рдЕрддрд┐ рддреЗрдереЗ рдорд╛рддреА': Eating too much makes you sick; studying too little makes you fail тАФ excess in either direction harms.
'рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рддрд│реЗ рд╕рд╛рдЪреЗ': Saving тВ╣10 daily = тВ╣3,650 per year. Small consistent savings become a significant amount.
'рдЧрд░реНрд╡рд╛рдЪреЗ рдШрд░ рдЦрд╛рд▓реА': A student who is overconfident before an exam and doesn't study ends up failing тАФ pride's downfall.
Proverbs (рдореНрд╣рдгреА) are different from quotes (рд╕реБрд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░) тАФ рдореНрд╣рдгреА are anonymous folk wisdom; рд╕реБрд╡рд┐рдЪрд╛рд░ are attributed to specific people.

keyPoints: 'рдЕрддрд┐ рддреЗрдереЗ рдорд╛рддреА' тАФ Excess leads to harm; moderation is wise in all things.
'рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рдереЗрдВрдмреЗ рддрд│реЗ рд╕рд╛рдЪреЗ' тАФ Small consistent efforts/savings accumulate into big results.
'рдЧрд░реНрд╡рд╛рдЪреЗ рдШрд░ рдЦрд╛рд▓реА' тАФ Arrogance/overconfidence leads to downfall.
рдореНрд╣рдгреА are traditional folk wisdom тАФ anonymous, tested by generations of Marathi speakers.
Using appropriate рдореНрд╣рдгреА in Marathi essays (рдирд┐рдмрдВрдз) and speeches makes them richer and more persuasive.

Many рдореНрд╣рдгреА are specifically about farming, seasons, family, and village life тАФ reflecting Maharashtra's predominantly rural heritage.

test.question: In the correct priority order, what does the 3R principle stand for?
test.explanation: The 3R stands for Reduce (reduce consumption first тАФ the most impactful), then Reuse (find new uses for existing items), then Recycle (process materials into new products).
